description: The Ezekiel-Revelation parallels constitute perhaps the most extensive Old Testament intertextual relationship in John's Apocalypse. Ezekiel's throne vision (chapter 1) directly informs Revelation 4's heavenly scene; the four living creatures derive from Ezekiel's chayot; the sealed scroll (Ezekiel 2-3) becomes Revelation's seven-sealed book; the temple vision (Ezekiel 40-48) shapes the New Jerusalem; Gog and Magog (Ezekiel 38-39) appear in Revelation 20; and the river of life (Ezekiel 47) flows through the holy city. John assumes his readers know Ezekiel and transforms these prophetic texts for Christian eschatological purposes.
longDescription:
Ezekiel provides foundational imagery throughout Revelation. The major parallels include:

The Throne Vision (Ezekiel 1 // Revelation 4):
Ezekiel's inaugural vision presents four living creatures (chayot), each with four faces and four wings, bearing the divine throne-chariot (merkabah). Above the expanse is 'a throne of lapis lazuli, and high above on the throne was a figure like that of a man.' In Revelation 4, four living creatures surround God's throne, each with a single distinctive face (lion, ox, human, eagle), covered with eyes. While John simplifies and adapts, Ezekiel's throne vision clearly underlies his heavenly scene.

The Four Living Creatures:
Ezekiel 1:5-14 describes four creatures with composite features. Revelation 4:6-8 adapts these while adding elements from Isaiah's seraphim (six wings). The fusion creates the distinctive 'zoa' of Revelation - creatures that lead heavenly worship and summon the horsemen.

The Scroll Consumed (Ezekiel 2:9-3:3 // Revelation 10:8-11):
Ezekiel receives a scroll 'written on both sides... with words of lament and mourning and woe' and eats it - 'it tasted as sweet as honey.' In Revelation 10, John similarly eats a little scroll that is 'sweet as honey in my mouth, but when I had eaten it, my stomach turned sour.' Both prophets are commissioned through consuming the divine word.

Gog and Magog (Ezekiel 38-39 // Revelation 20:7-10):
Ezekiel's extensive oracle against Gog becomes a brief but crucial element in Revelation's millennium vision. The nations 'from the four corners of the earth - Gog and Magog' represent the final rebellion after Satan's release.

The Temple Vision (Ezekiel 40-48 // Revelation 21-22):
Ezekiel's elaborate temple vision includes detailed measurements, gates, priests, and a river flowing from the temple bringing life wherever it goes. Revelation radically reinterprets this: the New Jerusalem has no temple, 'because the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple' (21:22). Yet the river of life and tree of life (Ezekiel 47) flow through the city (Revelation 22:1-2).

The Marking/Sealing (Ezekiel 9:4-6 // Revelation 7:3; 14:1):
In Ezekiel, a man with a writing kit marks the foreheads of those grieving over Jerusalem's abominations, protecting them from slaughter. In Revelation, the 144,000 are sealed on their foreheads with God's name, protected from judgments.
historicalContext:
Ezekiel prophesied during the Babylonian exile (593-571 BCE), addressing the destruction of Jerusalem's temple and the promise of restoration. His visions of a new temple and renewed land shaped Jewish messianic expectation for centuries.

John's appropriation of Ezekiel assumes a readership steeped in prophetic tradition. The merkabah (divine chariot) imagery was central to Jewish mysticism developing in the first centuries CE. John both participates in this tradition and Christianizes it around the Lamb.

The textual traditions of both books are well-preserved. John's allusions to Ezekiel are so extensive that scholars have identified over 100 verbal and thematic connections. Unlike his use of Daniel (which often follows Theodotion), John's Ezekiel allusions often reflect his own Greek rendering of the Hebrew.

The radical transformation of Ezekiel's temple (removing the temple structure entirely while retaining other features) represents John's most dramatic theological adaptation. Christ and the Lamb replace the temple; unmediated divine presence supersedes mediated worship.
theologicalSignificance:
The Ezekiel-Revelation connection establishes important theological principles:

1. Prophetic Continuity and Transformation: John doesn't simply repeat Ezekiel but radically reinterprets him through Christological lenses. The temple disappears because Christ fulfills its function.

2. Temple Theology: Ezekiel's temple restoration hopes find surprising fulfillment - not in a rebuilt structure but in God's unmediated presence with his people.

3. Divine Presence: Both prophets center on God's dwelling with his people. Ezekiel ends 'THE LORD IS THERE' (48:35); Revelation fulfills this through the tabernacling presence (21:3).

4. Prophetic Calling: Both prophets are commissioned through scroll-eating, emphasizing that they speak God's words, not their own.

5. Judgment and Restoration: Both move from judgment (on Jerusalem/Babylon) to glorious restoration (new temple/New Jerusalem).

6. Divine Protection: The marking/sealing motif assures God's people of protection through judgment.

keyPassages.text: Above the vault over their heads was what looked like a throne of lapis lazuli, and high above on the throne was a figure like that of a man. I saw that from what appeared to be his waist up he looked like glowing metal, as if full of fire, and that from there down he looked like fire; and brilliant light surrounded him. Like the appearance of a rainbow in the clouds on a rainy day, so was the radiance around him.
keyPassages.significance: The throne vision foundational to Revelation 4

keyPassages.text: I saw water coming out from under the threshold of the temple toward the east... Where the river flows everything will live... Fruit trees of all kinds will grow on both banks of the river. Their leaves will not wither, nor will their fruit fail. Every month they will bear fruit... Their fruit will serve for food and their leaves for healing.
keyPassages.significance: The river and trees of life appearing in Revelation 22

keyPassages.text: And the name of the city from that time on will be: THE LORD IS THERE.
keyPassages.significance: The divine presence fulfilled in New Jerusalem

keyPassages.text: I did not see a temple in the city, because the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple.
keyPassages.significance: John's radical transformation of Ezekiel's temple vision

comparativeNotes.merkabahMysticism: Ezekiel's throne vision became foundational to Jewish merkabah mysticism. The Hekhalot literature (3rd-7th centuries CE) developed elaborate practices for ascending through heavenly palaces to the divine chariot. John participates in this tradition while centering it on Christ.
comparativeNotes.templeReinterpretation: John's removal of the temple represents a dramatic interpretive move. While Ezekiel 40-48 expects a physical rebuilt temple, John declares that God and the Lamb ARE the temple. This reflects early Christian conviction that Jesus fulfilled and superseded temple worship.
comparativeNotes.secondTempleJudaism: The Qumran community also reinterpreted Ezekiel's temple vision, seeing themselves as a spiritual temple while awaiting eschatological restoration. John's move is more radical - the New Jerusalem has no temple because divine presence is fully unmediated.

author: Ezekiel (Prophet), John (Apostle)
